question_text: Does the stick shift move just like in a real car?

answers.answer_text:
No it doesn't, it moves to where they are supposed to go but there is no spring that returns the stick shift to the neutral position after you take it out of gear. It kind of just sits there.  In real cars the stick shift springs to center below 3rd gear and above 4th gear.  This makes it so when you go from 2nd gear to 3rd gear you just have to push the stick up, instead of up, then right then up again.  With the springing to center you just push it up and when it gets to neutral it springs right by itself and you just continue pushing it up to 3rd gear.  (Sorry for the explanation which you probably already know, but it's for others who don't.)

question_text: if all I want is to play games, is 4GB good enough, I dont need or want all the bells and whistles, just gameplay

You effectively need the hard drive, and it's cheaper and easier to just buy the system with it already installed...skip this 4GB model.

4GB is plenty for game saves, however, some games require a hard-drive to use certain features or sometimes even to function at all. The 4GB storage does not function the same as a hard drive. It is like a built in memory card/flash drive. Games that require a hard drive to run will say so on the box. Games that only need the hard drive for certain game modes (like "Halo Reach" requires a hard drive for Firefight or Online Co-op) will not say so on the box I believe. This is something to keep in mind.
I know I'm late but, if you don't have a lot of games 4 gb is fine, but if you have a lot then you will need to upgrade or delete some of your saves.

question_text: How bad is the violence and "Blood"? I have a 6 yr old dying to get this game, but I want to make sure it's appropriate. Please help.

answers.answer_text: This game has absolutely no blood and very little violence (cartoon sword slashing and fighting of the sort) and it's full of puzzles in which you could cooperate with your child to solve. It's good to develop those puzzle-solving skills and strengthen your bonds at the same time.

Like most Zelda games, the violence is cartoony and the monsters are stylized and not human-like. That being said, there's still sword slashing, arrow shooting and boomerang throwing, but all still cartoony.

The violence is on par with the rest of the series.  You do fight things though.   As for blood I don't recall ever seeing any.  It's cartoonish violence not realism.   I let my 9 year olds play.  It's more strategy and quests type game than a violent game.  Check out some YouTube clips to see what you think.  Personally, I'd let a 6 year old play if they wanted to.

There is no blood whatsoever. There might be a couple of fighting scenes with monster slime, but it's all purple and cartoony. There is fighting, with swords, arrows, etc., but once again, all cartoony. Frankly the few 'Tom and Jerry' shows I've seen are 3 times more violent than any LoZ game I've played. In this game, the worst thing that happens is 'Game over', and it's just Link staggering around a little and falling over. Suffice to say if your 6 y/o has seen Tangled, Frozen, Brave, or pretty much any PG movie, he/she will be just fine. :)

The violence is very cartoonish and there is no blood. Zelda games are about adventure and are full of puzzles. They are perfect for critical thinking and problem solving, which are great skills for a 6 year old to start working on. You should definitely get this game for your child.

There is one cutscene that even I was surprised Nintendo displayed, and it involved a sword being thrust into a character's head. There is no blood in this scene but it was easily one of the most violent things I saw in the series up to that point, that is when I played the Gamecube original (not sure if the HD remake contains the same scene). Other than that, most of the violence is mild and cartoony with a lot of character expression to sell the silliness.

The game doesn't have blood, and the violence is cartoony. But you might want to keep in mind that the ESRB gave it a ranking of E, meaning for 10 years and up. The puzzles and the bosses might frighten a little kid.
This is the best possible game for a young child's imagination, if they are curiosity and courage driven.

question_text: Is it all strictly PvP or is there some PvE as well?

answers.answer_text: It's almost all PvE - the PvP is optional.

Based on my in-game experience, "The Elder Scrolls Online" is a great game for both PVE and PVP type of players.  Because this huge world of Tamriel and part of Oblivion is so massive and full of so many things to do, both end game for PVP and PVE players types may be just a little less than what people are wishing for.  Myself, my wife, and our 4 friends have been playing since launch and loving our adventures in game.  A lot of people complain about the game because some player types (MMO / RPG) are only focused on what they are looking for, but they are still playing the game. This game is a monumental achievement if I may say, and we love playing in it.  (By the way, two of my friends are avid MMOers) The best part of TESO is combat because you have to be engaged and react to mobs or PvPers to win a fight.  You actually must have a gameplan with group or buddy to ease through the fights and battles.  The quickest way to die is to set macros (pre-set combat sequences) because my friend tried this and never used macros again.  The best TESO innovation compared to all other MMOs/RPGs is their combat design.  If you are planning on ordering this game, seriosly consider spending a few more dollars on the "Imperial Edition"  because in addition to added treasure maps, you get a white horse or two per character for only 1 gold per white horse.

The majority of the world is PvE and is probably about what you'd expect from a massively multiplayer Elder Scrolls world. The world is pretty huge and divided into three sections -- one for each alliance (Daggerfall, Ebonheart, Aldmeri). They meet around Cyrodiil, which is a massive PvP/war zone. Everything inside Cyrodiil (including PvE quest hubs and dungeons) is all open to PvP. There is no PvP outside of Cyrodiil.
Alot of PVE mainly but it does support a decent amount of pvp so far.
There is tons of PvE, in fact I don't care for the PvP part of the game, it is too difficult unless you are with a large group of players.
There is a ton of PvE content. I just didn't find it compelling.

As an update since April, not much has changed in the PvP areas of ESO. In fact, PvP is more-or-less an afterthought and really only available in one area, Cyrodiil. There's not a specifically designed area, like an Arena, where you can go and just PvP battle it out with other players. This would have been a better choice. Instead, ZeniMax overlapped PvP and PvE areas together so PvP players continually go after PvE players while trying to quest. It was a bad design decision by ZeniMax and makes the game far less enjoyable for PvE-focused players. The PvE that is there is not really as fun as the PvE in Skyrim or Oblivion because the game engine is just not quite up to that level.

Instead, ZeniMax overlapped PvP and PvE areas together so PvP players continually go after PvE players while trying to quest. It was a bad design decision by ZeniMax and makes the game far less enjoyable for PvE-focused players. The PvE that is there is not really as fun as the PvE in Skyrim or Oblivion because the game engine is just not quite up to that level.
      « 

Show Less

There is PvE, but it does not feel like a TES game, more like a generic MMO where you can only wander so far before being killed by enemies of a higher level. The PVP is what will keep players subscribing though. If you're expecting to explore a large world like you do in the single player Elder Scrolls games, you will be pretty disappointed.
There is some of both PvP is kind of week/poor and optional something to do if bored, and it's lacking any proper end game / elder game for PvE but it's mainly PvE focused just not the greatest PvE.
Both!  I have yet to use PvP mode and there is much to do in PvE.

At $20 it is a heckuva deal.One tip for users: The default max tire steering angle for each car is ~14-15 degrees. At this setting, the cars are unresponsive and feel like they understeer badly as you go off the corners.  The solution is to go into Car Setup> General, and change the steer angle to 21-23 degrees (you have to do this every time)!  That makes the car much more responsive to steering inputs and you'll be able to stay on track at higher speeds.

question_text: PS4 users, while playing and chatting, are there any cables connected to/from the headset/controller? or only cables between console/transmitter?

answers.answer_text: You must use a chat cable between headset and controller.

question_text: Is this headset worth the money ? as all the reviews i been seeing is it the best headset ? ill be using it for PC with ASUS Xonar Essence Stx?

answers.answer_text: For flat and accurate sound it's up with the best. It's not the most ideal for bassy music but it will hit all the notes. The Xonar is good, these are only 32 ohm and can be powered by most sources.

that's a very subjective question; however i'll apply it to my own review.  are they amazing, YES.  will you need a soundcard and/ or dac/amp(<-what i have) to get this puppy juicing out?  YES, without it, it was mediocre at best. is it great for gaming?  NO.  when you talk, you will not be able to hear yourself due to the enclosed earcups.  build quality?  YES - it's something that will be handed down generations.  worth the price?  If your purpose is to mainly listen to music at the highest quality, then yes - although this is assuming you have a DAC/AMP properly pushing these headphones.  otherwise, it's like having a top of the line subwoofer in your trunk without anything pushing power to the sub.  if you're willing to sacrifice about 10% in music quality but gain 40% in PC Gaming sound, then i'd go with a pair of open eared sennheisers for half the price.  otherwise, with these you'll be gaining 10% music quality, but downgrading 40% in pc gaming sound.so, as i originally stated, it's subjective.  depends on what YOU'RE looking for.  it's expensive AF too but if you're not happy, just return 'em.

question_text: is there a better gaming headphone than this? or this is top of the line?

answers.answer_text: I've owned about 5 headsets in the last 2 years. This has been the best headset I've found on the market when it comes to sound and mic quality. It does lack features like mic mute when boom is up and on can volume controls.

It's expensive.  For a closed headphone, it is good. I think it's pretty much the DT770 32ohm with an attached mic.  However, the mic itself leaves much to be desired for the price. Finally, since mine have gone out of warranty, while they still sound great, they are physically disintegrating.

I have had a lot of headiets and this is the best one yet. Paired with my creative zxr sound card I hear way more then I ever did before and they super comfortable. I would recommend to anyone who has the money to purchase.

question_text: Why is it mature?

Like LEGO games; isn't it morbid to hit someone and have them explode into pieces? ;) Just saying, this game has violence but it is very mild. question_text: does this stick come with a cd at all and is this batter then hotas warhog.

answers.answer_text: no & no

If you have internet, there is no reason for it to come with a CD; instructions tell you where to download the updated drivers.As to better than the Warthog, probably not, but it's nearly $300 less expensive, so...

No CD as Internet is suppose to take the place.  For the Warthog, it might be better, it all depends on you and not what specs each have.  For one, the Warthog does not have yaw, therefore you will need to buy peddles or find a way to reprogram a button to serve as your yaw.  This does make the Warthog far sturdier and gives it a more realistic feel.  Also, the switches on the Warthog are all toggle as these on the x55 serve more as buttons.  But nevertheless, if you need yaw or non-toggle switches, you will think the Warthog is garbage compared to this.  Yes, the Warthog has been rated better, but personal preference trumps all reviews.  Do your research into what exactly you're getting and see if it's what you want or need out of a joystick.  Or do as I did when I purchased the x55, I bought three different HOTAS joysticks, tested and returned two.  One returned being the Warthog as I figured if I was going for it, I might as well go big.  It felt too much for my needs and the x55 was just about right.  There are a few videos you will find on YouTube where people went from an x52/x55 to a Warthog and most of them say how disappointed they are in the change as wish to go back to the x52/x55.  All in all, both joysticks have great specs, but it's all about preference.

For one, the Warthog does not have yaw, therefore you will need to buy peddles or find a way to reprogram a button to serve as your yaw. But nevertheless, if you need yaw or non-toggle switches, you will think the Warthog is garbage compared to this.  Yes, the Warthog has been rated better, but personal preference trumps all reviews.  Do your research into what exactly you're getting and see if it's what you want or need out of a joystick.  Or do as I did when I purchased the x55, I bought three different HOTAS joysticks, tested and returned two.  One returned being the Warthog as I figured if I was going for it, I might as well go big.  It felt too much for my needs and the x55 was just about right.  There are a few videos you will find on YouTube where people went from an x52/x55 to a Warthog and most of them say how disappointed they are in the change as wish to go back to the x52/x55.  All in all, both joysticks have great specs, but it's all about preference.

question_text: For those of you that have bigger hands, does this "fit" well? I have bigger hands and its hard to find peripherals that "fit" comfortably.

answers.answer_text: I'm 6'4" (1.93 m) with fairly large hands and it fits great.
Well you can adjust the pad, so I would say yes but I don't have really big hands.

There are big hands and there are BIG hands...That said, I am one of the former, a slightly larger than average sized person with large hands and the keypad works well for me.  The adjustable palm rest helps to keep the keys at the proper distance from your palm so your hand isn't cramped.  Key spacing is a bit more generous than an average keyboard.  If a basketball looks like a volleyball in your hands, probably nearly any keypad will be too small.

I'm 6'2" / 205lbs, so I have fairly large hands. This device fits me hand just fine. If you have very large hands you may have issues with the lower row outside keys, but I haven't experienced any problems. The palm grip slides out a bit,which helps.

question_text: looking into getting  a ps4 for Christmas I played the first game and really liked it is this game on par or better then the first infamous?

They also give you the choice to switch between the different powers when ever you want!  The only con about the game, imo, is the minor differences between the good/evil power sets; they are pretty much the same, but the different powers you get makes up for it.  Overall I give this game a 9; and I recommend it to all ps4 players!  Happy gaming!

It depends on how you run the headphones from your source. The cable is braided, but (like most logitech braided cables) it's pretty limp. i haven't had it tangle, but I run the cable at full length most of the time. I'd say it's pretty manageable.

The cord is about 7 ft I think but the distance to the inline volume and mic control is 18-20 inches, the rest allows you to be a good distance from your PC and what you done need can easily be wrapped in a bundle and Velcro strapped in a bunch. The unit has a Velcro wrap attached to the cord so it won't get lost. Buy  these headsets, the sound is outstanding for the price.

The wire is very, very long, so you would need to roll it and secure with an small strap. Nevertheless, the long wire would allow you to be far from th computer or the game set in order to play. Also, if you use this headphones to listen from a  TV set or anorher sound equipment far from you are sitting or in bed, this long wore will allow you to be far without disconnecting. I hope this answer would help.

Not at all because it is wrapped in fabric cord. It comes with a velcro strap so you can wrap up the cord under the volume control if you want to shorten it (cuz it's loooong). You also use a normal twist tie for the part above the volume control (un-coiled the volume control is like 2 ft long) Fantastic headset btw :D.
No b/c it has a Velcro strap to keep all the loose wires all neat clean  and together
I haven't had any issues with the wires tangling. I have three cats all of whom think the cord is a plaything, they chew and toy with it constantly. And so far, zero issues.

question_text: How would this work if buying as a gift?

answers.answer_text: I gifted to hubby.  You will get an email with a set of codes for each expansion.  I believe hubby went to play station store and had an option to redeem codes.You will get instructions on redeeming with your email. You would give the three codes you will be given after purchasing to whomever would be receiving them as a gift. Amazon makes it really simple!  Easiest might be to just purchase a gift card.  But when you purchase the Skyrim DLC (Down Loadable Content) you get a code and instructions on how to use the code on the gaming box. question_text: Does it pay to get a used x52 pro. The Warthog is close to $500 and the less than stellar reviews for this item on Amazon and elsewhere are scary.

answers.answer_text: The X52's stick was way to loose for me for precision corrections. It also had a dead zone that I just didn't like.  X-55 is much, much better.

You will pay to get the x52 pro, but you probably wont regret it. If this is your first stick, then it is a fantastic buy. My X-52 non pro has lasted me through years of fun. Plus, the Warthog does not include yaw (rudder) control at all while the X-52, X-52 Pro, and X-55 all do. The joystick twists and acts as the rudder.

No in all honestly I really enjoy the X-55. I've had no troubles with it at all. If your worried about the phantom button presses that some people have complained about, use a powered usb hub. Works perfect with that. I use the X-55 for elite: dangerous, start citizen, and dcs world. My X-55 had over 100 hours on it.
it is not $500, it is $200 and it is a very good flight stick for simulation and for recreational games.

question_text: How's the wireless range on this thing compare to the gold version?

question_text: do you need a kinect to use any of the remotes funtions?

answers.answer_text: No. Just the xbox one.

It's not impossible to do it without a kinect, but it is difficult. The kinect works as a middle man between the Xbox and the TV. Without the TV and Xbox 'synced' you can't use the media remote to turn up your TV volume or anything.
It seems like the remote uses the infrared technology in the Kinect. I would say, yes.
No

No, a Kinect is not required to use this remote with the Xbox One. To connect your headphones to your Samsung S4, follow these steps:

1. Open the Bluetooth setting on your S4, where it searches for and can be found by Bluetooth devices.
2. Power on your headphones and press the multifunction button (the short one on the left can) for 7 seconds to start pairing mode.
3. When "Ravetouch" appears in the device list on your S4, tap to connect. No code should be required.

Alternatively, you can also try putting your phone in a state to be recognized by the device, holding the button for it to flash red and blue, and then hitting "Search" to connect.

If you need further assistance or a PDF copy of the user manual, you can contact support@whitelabel.co.

question_text: Exactly what kind of game is this?

answers.answer_text: You get to read a manga style comic book.  You will get to make some desicions that will affect the outcome.  You may wanna check out some game play video on you tube.

It is a visual novel/romance sim. It is all cut scenes (detailed art work) with dialouge choices forming the main branches of the storyline. There is no kind of fighting/action elements whatsoever. Please refer to my review on this game for further explanation...it's a great game if you go for storyline and artwork, but if you want something a little more fast-paced and action-geared, you should probably stay clear.

This game is a 'Otome' game, it's basically aimed mostly towards a female audience. But compared to other games in that genre I think this game can be just as interesting for guys to play since the storyline is very good. While the game is a dating-sim it has a very interesting story that could very well have been it's own game without all the romance and the text is exceptionally written as well. The goal while playing game is to pair Chizuru with one of the six guys available, or the neutral path where she ends up alone so if you don't like romance this game is not for you, however it's not sickly sweet romance it is added in a nice amount and the story is just as important, if not more, than the romance, most of the characters you meet as well as the war and it's locations are taken from history and existed in real life so that makes it even more interesting. It's also text heavy since it is a visual novel, basically a novel read on a TV screen, so if you prefer action and fighting in games this is not for you either, throughout the game you will move the text forward by pressing the x-button and occasionally pick an option between a couple of choices, these choices will determine which guy Chizuru will end up with. I really recommend this game if you like a good story, japanese culture/history and some added romance.

question_text: I bought the it  but I don't know how to use it?

answers.answer_text: I suppose that if you buy it, you know what's it's for, that is to use with a plane simulator (the Joystick is used for pitch and roll control, and pedals for rudder/yaw control); Depending of what sort of sim. software you use, settings for this devise is generaly in the same control panel than the joystick one. On Windows you'll perhaps need to installe the drivers for it (for Mac nothing to do, as usual, it runs)

How to install into Microsoft Flight Simulator X on a computer using Microsoft Windows:  (1) plug the USB into one of the computer's USB port.  (2) Start Microsoft Flight simulator X. Fly. It should setup itself.  If the rudder does not seem to work, do #3. (3) Click Settings | Controls. Under Controller Type, select CH PRO PEDALS USB.  Click Calibration, verify the sensitivity is to your liking. Click Control Axis. Make sure it is showing Brake (left axis) as X Axis, Brake (right axis) as Y Axis, and Rudder Axis as Z Axis.Flying: The rudder peddles work the same way as they do in a real airplane, push the bottom of the peddle with the heals of your foot to move the rudder. To break, push the top of the peddles with the toes and balls of your heals.  There is no simulated wind resistance that is found in a real airplane. If you have been flying a real airplane, then using the peddles will be easy.  If you have not been flying a real airplane, then flying with the peddles will take time and practice.

They are not too expensive, so if you still wish to do so, you can. 1) Buy a USB External Sound Card ( Virtual 5.1-surround USB 2.0 External Sound Card ) -- now the only other problem is: it is one 3.5mm, so it has 3 rings, 1 for each speaker (2) and 1 for a microphone. So you will need to buy a 2) A 3.5mm to headset adapter so that you can plug both in the above item (plugged into the PS3 USB ports.) ( Consumer Electronic Products Smartphone Headset to PC Adapter - Use a 3.5mm iPhone/Smartphone Headset With Your PC, Converts 3.5mm Plug to Dual Mic/Audio 3.5mm, for Skype/VOIP (01-PH35-PC35) Supply Store ) Using this, you can change the original 3.5mm to 2 3.5mm (headphone and microphone) and then plug into usb hookup, then connect the usb to the PS3, which will work.

question_text: Corsair Vengeance K70 or CM Storm QuickFire TK?

answers.answer_text:
That is a difficult question, since the form factor differs on the two.  Not quite comparing apples to apples.  I looked up the CM Storm QuickFire TK and I see they incorporated the DLT-PrtScn-Arrow Key section as 2nd Functions into the Numpad area.  This smaller form factor decreases the distance between your left and right hand and may be more comfortable for your shoulders, or that's atleast the idea.  I haven't owned a smaller form factor keyboard myself.Form factor wise it would be better to compare the K65 with the CM Storm QuickFire TK.  The QuickFire TK would win hands down, because of a lack of features on the K65- no wrist rest, back-lighting, etc.The K70 has a very nice volume controller on the keyboard and dedicated media keys, but if you don't use media keys that often or if you do, but don't mind using them as a 2nd Function, it doesn't matter that much not having them as dedicated keys.The K70 has a very nice wrist rest and this may sound stupid, but this wins high points for me with the K70, since when I use a desktop keyboard really alot, I get keyboard wrist inflammation, if that is even a term.  I bought a wrist gel (3M make for both my keyboard and mouse) months before I decided on which mechanical keyboard I was going to buy so that I wouldn't prefer one over the other just because of this add-on and so that I would have one if I decided to go with a keyboard without one.  I used that gel wrist rest with my mouse, and it worked for a decent amount of months to stop the small frequent friction of my wrist against the mousepad/wooden table, but then I started to get a lasting pain a little higher up in my wrist because of the declining position I had to hold my wrist in to use the mouse with the wrist rest.That said, I have no problems with the K70 wrist rest, and that just shows how well designed it is and how even if you buy a separate wrist rest, it will probably not be as comfortable as the one provided with the K70.Subjectively for me, I would go with the K70 instead of the CM Storm QuickFire TK, since I enjoy the dedicated media keys and volume controller and its wrist rest.  At the time I bought my K70, only the cherry mx red version was available.  I would advise you to go with the cherry mx brown version out now since it has a little bit of a tactile feedback.  Also, get yourself some rubber o-rings from amazon that reduces the key travel by supposedly 2mm and reduces bottoming out noise.  I use it myself, trust me, it works very well.You might want to wait if you want more back-light color options on your keyboard since the corsair K70 RGB is almost out (all though only with cherry mx red keys at the moment, I would advise cherry mx browns, like I said).  It gives you options to all the colors of the rainbow and more.  It cost $40 more than the regular K70 version, so it's up to you if it is worth the cost.If you have to go for a keyboard now, I would say get the corsair K70 cherry mx brown.  I also use the textured key-caps W, S and D, not the A since it is curved to the left and for the purposes I use it, I don't find it comfortable.  These textured key-caps are quite nice for a little extra tactile feel.

question_text: Do I need an HD tv for an Xbox One?

answers.answer_text:
Yes and no.  Let me explain.  The Xbox One only comes with an HDMI out.  However, you can purchase cables/converters that will go HDMI-> component or standard A/V.  I can't recommend any b/c I don't have any personal experience with them but if you search on Amazon you'll find plenty.  But keep in mind the Xbox One is geared toward HD content and games.  If you don't use an HD TV you are not getting the full benefit of the console.  It would be like buying a sports car and never driving over 40 MPH.  If you are going to shell out the almost $500.00 for the Xbox One then you owe it to yourself to upgrade your TV too.  HD content will become the norm.  Lastly, as of now most of the games for the One are being produced for the 360, which does have standard outputs.  So if you don't have a HD TV now stick with the 360 and wait till you upgrade your TV.  Also, if you look there are very few One games out now.  Over the next few months more will be coming out but there is a very small pool of One games.  So you may be better off waiting till you upgrade your TV to buy a One anyway.  Hope this helps.

question_text: Does this work with the newer flat screen Tv's? How does the picture look with it?

answers.answer_text:
In order to work with the TV, the TV must have an OTA or "over the air" tuner, to be able to tune into the legacy channels 2-13 (VHF). If your tv does not have this type of input, you may still be able to connect it through an older VCR. If you don't have a VCR, your local thrift shop is sure to have one, but get it quick before they're all gone :) Make sure that the VCR has composite outputs that are compatible with your new digital television. If you TV only has HDMI, you should have got a different tv. You can also get an RF to composite adapter box, but these are quite pricy ($150)

question_text: does this work with balance board

answers.answer_text: Yes

Yes, it does. Setup of the Wii Balance Board: Before you start using your Wii Balance Board, you'll have to synchronise it with (or in other words, "connect to") your Wii console.To do this simply insert the Wii Fit Plus disc and start the game. After the title screen has displayed, open the battery compartment on the underside of the Wii Balance Board as well as the SD Card slot cover on the front of the Wii console.Inside each of these compartments is a small red SYNC button - push and release this button on the Wii Balance Board once and also push the button on the Wii console once. You'll see the light on the Power Button of the Wii Balance Board flash. Once the light has finished flashing and remains lit the synchronisation is complete and you're ready to go.Note that only one Wii Balance Board can be synchronised with a given Wii console.Also note that only one Wii console can register a certain Wii Balance Board. If a registered Wii Balance Board is then synchronised with another Wii console using the procedure above, the settings of the Wii Balance Board will be overwritten. To re-use it with the initial Wii console, it will be necessary to perform the above steps again. Source: https://www.nintendo.co.uk/Support/Wii/Usage/Wii-Balance-Board/Setup-of-the-Wii-Balance-Board/Setup-of-the-Wii-Balance-Board-240188.html     You're welcome!

   Yes, it does. Setup of the Wii Balance Board: Before you start using your Wii Balance Board, you'll have to synchronise it with (or in other words, "connect to") your Wii console.To do this simply insert the Wii Fit Plus disc and start the game. After the title screen has displayed, open the battery compartment on the underside of the Wii Balance Board as well as the SD Card slot cover on the front of the Wii console.Inside each of these compartments is a small red SYNC button - push and release this button on the Wii Balance Board once and also push the button on the Wii console once. You'll see the light on the Power Button of the Wii Balance Board flash. Once the light has finished flashing and remains lit the synchronisation is complete and you're ready to go.Note that only one Wii Balance Board can be synchronised with a given Wii console.Also note that only one Wii console can register a certain Wii Balance Board. If a registered Wii Balance Board is then synchronised with another Wii console using the procedure above, the settings of the Wii Balance Board will be overwritten. To re-use it with the initial Wii console, it will be necessary to perform the above steps again. Source: https://www.nintendo.co.uk/Support/Wii/Usage/Wii-Balance-Board/Setup-of-the-Wii-Balance-Board/Setup-of-the-Wii-Balance-Board-240188.html     You're welcome!
